text: today I'm going to share with you a
really great and easy recipe for a
caramel custard and you're going to make
the caramel from scratch by combining a
half a cup of sugar with some water in a
saucepan over like a medium-high heat
the water is really just there to help
the sugar dissolve and dissolve all of
the crystals so the original recipe does
call for a cup of water but you just
have to boil off all of that water so
I'm adding much less than a cup of water
because it's only half a cup of sugar
you just want to dissolve your sugar
crystals into the water get them
completely dissolved and then stop doing
anything don't stir it you can swirl the
pan a little bit as it starts to
caramelize but you really don't want to
do too much the bubbles are starting to
be a little bit bigger a little bit more
slow-moving that's how you know your
sugar is starting to cook it hasn't
changed color at all yet but it's going
to start changing color soon and when it
does it goes really fast so this is not
the time to leave your stove you got to
stand here and you got to watch it but
it doesn't take too too long so what
usually happens is that the caramel
starts cooking from the outside in but
because of where the heat is
concentrated on this burner it's
actually starting on the inside and
going out so I'm still allowed to swirl
though so it's starting to look closed
this is the kind of scary part because
the caramel is SuperDuper dark and you
have to pour cold half-and-half into
your pan it's gonna bubble up like crazy
if you're not careful it will completely
boil over the cold half-and-half might
make the caramel set just a little bit
but don't worry because you have to
bring it back and bring it back to
temperature and heat it up so it's gonna
get little lumps which will dissolve as
you bring your mixture back to a boil
so now I'm feeling that there are
solidified caramel bits on the bottom of
my pan and I'm going to bring my mixture
back to a boil to absorb all of that
slip by tamo
while this is coming to a boil I'm gonna
get my egg mixture ready and that's
what's gonna thicken my custard in the
oven I have eight egg yolks here to that
I'm adding two teaspoons of vanilla
extract and a quarter teaspoon of coarse
salt give it a stir and right when
you're about ready to add your hot cream
mixture you're gonna add a half a cup of
sugar you don't want to add it too soon
because what happens is the sugar
crystals and the egg yolks react
together and they make these weird lumps
we call it cooking it even though
technically it's not cooking it and you
don't want to do it too far ahead or you
ruin all your yolks so I'm gonna wait to
add my sugar until my half-and-half
mixture is almost ready to add all right
it's coming to a boil so I'm gonna turn
it off add my sugar it's or another half
a cup of sugar to the egg yolks stir it
in and then you want to gradually add
your caramel mixture to this sugar and
egg yolk mixture you can ladle it in you
can gradually pour it in if you feel
okay with that you just want to make
sure that you gradually add it so you
don't cook your egg yolks and that time
I mean you really don't want to cook
your egg yolks and when I say cook I
mean really cook so just gradually add
it you can add a little bit at a time
give it a stir this is called tempering
it's slowly increasing the temperature
of the egg yolk so that you can add a
hot mixture to egg yokes without cooking
it if you added it all at once you would
end up with little bits of cooked egg
which totally ruins the texture of your
custard because I'm going to be baking
these I have my oven preheating at 325
I'm not going to return this custard
mixture to the pot normally I would
return it to the pot and I would cook it
until it's thick there
but this is a baked custard and so
there's no need to do that you just
gradually add your hot half-and-half
mixture and just for safety's sake I
like to strain this through a fine sieve
and that will remove any bits of egg
that may have cooked and made little
lumps inevitably it happens so you want
to get rid of those and then you can
transfer it to the dishes these are six
ounce ramekins and I have them in a
baking dish just large enough to hold
them pour the mixture evenly between the
ramekins Wow it's so nice what a
beautiful color right you want to remove
some of this foam on the top because
that will actually bake onto the top and
then your custards will not be smooth on
top so you can remove it with a spoon
one of the tricks that professional
chefs use when they have bubbles in
their custard mixture is they run a
torch over the top and the torch the
fire pops all the bubbles but I'm going
low-tech here and just using a spoon
because this is actually very very
frothy I can also just let it sit for
like an hour who has an hour to let
their custard sit before they go in the
oven so have your oven at 325 degrees
and have some water boiling because in
order to make sure that these cook
really evenly and slowly what you're
going to want to do is add boiling water
to come about halfway up the sides of
the custard ramekins and then put it
into the oven covered and bake it until
they're just set in the center that will
take about 40 to 45 minutes
when you take them out of the oven
you're gonna want to let them cool and
then refrigerate until they're
completely cold
at least three hours and like up to
three days so you can totally make these
ahead which is great if you're having a
party oh look at the custard okay
look at it amazing silky amazingness
it's amazing twice that's how amazing it
is
mmm oh my gosh it's silky it's caramely
it's totally make-ahead it's a gift from
